Award.AwardTitle: Functional Patchy Nanoparticles by Interfacial Engineering
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Metal nanoparticles are generally stabilized with an organic capping layer, forming an organic shell-metal core structure. The materials properties and functions are therefore largely determined by these two components. With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research, this research project is focused on the development of effective procedures for the preparation of a special class of nanoparticle materials where the organic ligands as well as the metal components may be independently incorporated into the nanoparticles in a spatially controlled manner. This provides a unique way to further manipulate the nanoparticle structures and properties. Neapolitan nanoparticles are used as the initial illustrating examples, analogous to a layered Neapolitan cake with structurally distinct organic/metal components at the two poles and at the equatorial ring. These nanoparticles may be used to prepare more complicated nanoparticle materials and structures, and for electrocatalytic reduction of oxygen, a critical reaction at fuel cell cathode. The research activities are intimately integrated with various educational efforts, from on-hands training of diverse student researchers including graduate students, undergraduate students and high-school students.

Technical Abstract
The specific aim of this research project is to develop effective protocols based on deliberate interfacial engineering for the preparation of Neapolitan nanoparticles with a tri-patchy structure not only of the organic capping layers but also of the metal cores. This is built upon the prior success of the PI's laboratory in the preparation of amphiphilic Janus nanoparticles. In the present research project the focus is on Neapolitan nanoparticles that exhibit distinctly different chemical functionalities at the two poles and on the equatorial ring of the nanoparticles. Concurrently, the original monometallic nanoparticle cores may be converted to bimetallic or even trimetallic ones by taking advantage of galvanic exchange reactions between the nanoparticles and metal-thiolate complexes, with the second and third metals also distributed asymmetrically on the nanoparticle cores. The ready and independent manipulation of both the organic capping layers and the metal cores into segregated patches may be exploited for further and more complicated chemical functionalization of the nanoparticles. The fundamental insights are anticipated to further advance our understanding of the mechanisms that control the organized assembly of nanostructured materials in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The specific aim of this research project is to develop effective protocols based on deliberate interfacial engineering for the preparation of Janus nanoparticles that exhibit asymmetrical surface chemistry, to examine the organized assemblies of the resulting Janus nanoparticles, and to explore their applications in, for instance, chemical sensing and electrocatalysis. Within the award period, we have largely achieved these goals. Experimentally, for instance, we prepared two new Janus nanoparticles. One entailed thermoswitchable Janus nanoparticles functionalized with stimuli-responsive hydrophilic polymer brushes, and the other was focused on gold core@silver semishell Janus nanoparticles by chemical etching of Au@Ag core–shell nanoparticles at the air/water interface. Interestingly, the Au@Ag semishell Janus nanoparticles prepared above exhibited enhanced electrocatalytic activity in oxygen reduction reactions, as compared to their Au@Ag and Ag@Au core–shell counterparts, likely due to a synergistic effect between the gold cores and silver semishells that optimized oxygen binding to the nanoparticle surface. Because of structural asymmetry that resembles conventional surfactant molecules, the Janus nanoparticles can self-assemble into hollow, vesicle-like nanostructures. Recently, we observed that these hollow nanostructures actually exhibited apparent plasmonic circular dichroism (PCD) properties, although only achiral response was observed with individual nanoparticles. Theoretical studies based on first principle calculations showed that the PCD effect was due to the formation of a dipole vertex when the Janus nanoparticles were arranged into a hollow sphere. This chiral property could then be exploited for the detection and separation of enantiomers, as manifested in the sensing of D, and L forms of alanine and cysteine. In short, these research activities demonstrate that controlled spatial arrangement of the structural components of the nanoparticles may serve as a new, powerful variable in the manipulation of the nanoparticle structure and property, in addition to the conventional parameters of size, shape, and elemental composition. The research progress significantly expands the chemistry toolbox in nanoparticle functionalization, organization, and application.

 

On the broader impacts, the PI was actively involved in recruiting and mentoring of undergraduate andHigh school students in independent research. Within the award period, the PI supervised 12 undergraduate students in independent research (of these, Lewis Bonny, co-authored two research articles and was awarded the 2016 Fink Memorial Student Award, and both Wanzhang Pan (2017) and Carolin Wahl (2018) received an undergraduate research award), and 15 high-school students through the UCSC Science Internship Program (SIP). In addition, the PI was actively engaged in educational outreach. The PI designed and taught a cluster (Nanochemistry) for the UCSC COSMOS program (California Summer School for Mathematics and Science) for highly talented high school students. The curriculum includes daily lectures on the basics and potential applications of functional nanomaterials as well as five hands on labs where the students synthesize and characterize a series of nanoparticles such as Au, CdSe, Fe3O4, TiO2, etc. Field trips to prominent local industrial and national research facilities also allow the students to see how the basic knowledge discussed in the classroom can be used to solve practical problems and to appreciate the impacts of science and education on technologic development.


Last Modified: 05/31/2018
Modified by: Shaowei Chen
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The specific aim of this research project is to develop effective protocols based on deliberate interfacial engineering for the preparation of Janus nanoparticles that exhibit asymmetrical surface chemistry, to examine the organized assemblies of the resulting Janus nanoparticles, and to explore their applications in, for instance, chemical sensing and electrocatalysis. Within the award period, we have largely achieved these goals. Experimentally, for instance, we prepared two new Janus nanoparticles. One entailed thermoswitchable Janus nanoparticles functionalized with stimuli-responsive hydrophilic polymer brushes, and the other was focused on gold core@silver semishell Janus nanoparticles by chemical etching of Au@Ag core–shell nanoparticles at the air/water interface. Because of structural asymmetry that resembles conventional surfactant molecules, the Janus nanoparticles can self-assemble into hollow, vesicle-like nanostructures. Recently, we observed that these hollow nanostructures actually exhibited apparent plasmonic circular dichroism (PCD) properties, although only achiral response was observed with individual nanoparticles. In short, these research activities demonstrate that controlled spatial arrangement of the structural components of the nanoparticles may serve as a new, powerful variable in the manipulation of the nanoparticle structure and property, in addition to the conventional parameters of size, shape, and elemental composition. The research progress significantly expands the chemistry toolbox in nanoparticle functionalization, organization, and application. On the broader impacts, the PI was actively involved in recruiting and mentoring of undergraduate andHigh school students in independent research. Within the award period, the PI supervised 12 undergraduate students in independent research (of these, Lewis Bonny, co-authored two research articles and was awarded the 2016 Fink Memorial Student Award, and both Wanzhang Pan (2017) and Carolin Wahl (2018) received an undergraduate research award), and 15 high-school students through the UCSC Science Internship Program (SIP). In addition, the PI was actively engaged in educational outreach. The PI designed and taught a cluster (Nanochemistry) for the UCSC COSMOS program (California Summer School for Mathematics and Science) for highly talented high school students. The curriculum includes daily lectures on the basics and potential applications of functional nanomaterials as well as five hands on labs where the students synthesize and characterize a series of nanoparticles such as Au, CdSe, Fe3O4, TiO2, etc. Field trips to prominent local industrial and national research facilities also allow the students to see how the basic knowledge discussed in the classroom can be used to solve practical problems and to appreciate the impacts of science and education on technologic development.
